item.title: Explosions Reported in Venezuela’s Capital
item.description: It was not immediately clear what caused the blasts. The United States has been building pressure on Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s authoritarian president, for months.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: Smoke rising near La Carlota airport after explosions and low-flying aircraft were heard in Caracas, Venezuela, on Saturday.

item.title: Lenny Dykstra Faces Charges After Police Find Drugs During Traffic Stop
item.description: The Pennsylvania police did not say what charges would be filed against the former baseball star. His lawyer said the drugs were not Mr. Dykstra’s.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon

media:content.media:description: Lenny Dykstra in 2012.

item.title: How Kazakhstan Aims to Tap More Oil Riches Below Its Grassy Plains
item.description: After spending nearly $50 billion to expand the country’s Tengiz oil field, Chevron and its partners encounter more uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed and Desiré Van Den Berg

media:content.media:description: A new oil processing plant at Tengiz, part of a multibillion-dollar expansion that has increased the field’s capacity.

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 3, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 3, 2026.

item.title: ‘Chinese Peptides’ Are the Latest Biohacking Trend in the Tech World
item.description: The gray-market drugs flooding Silicon Valley reveal a community that believes it can move faster than the F.D.A.
item.dc:creator: Jasmine Sun

item.title: Diane Crump, First Woman to Ride in Kentucky Derby, Dies at 77
item.description: She was the first professional female jockey to compete at a track in the United States where betting was legal, and notched up 228 career victories.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman

media:content.media:description: Ms. Crump with her horse Fathom, whom she rode in the Kentucky Derby in 1970.

item.title: Federal Appeals Court Says California Open-Carry Ban Is Unconstitutional
item.description: A Ninth Circuit panel said the ban ran afoul of a 2022 Supreme Court ruling that required courts to evaluate gun laws based on the country’s “historical tradition of firearm regulation.”
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall

media:content.media:description: A Ninth Circuit panel determined that California’s restrictions on the open carrying of guns was unconstitutional.

item.title: 2 Navy Service Members Accused of Entering Sham Marriages With Chinese Nationals
item.description: Federal prosecutors say two female service members are facing fraud charges after having accepted thousands of dollars for the marriages.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: Two U.S. Navy service members are accused of participating in a scheme in which American citizens would marry Chinese nationals to help them obtain green cards.

item.title: Corner Piece
item.description: Hannah Slovut-Einertson’s puzzle sets solvers on a cool, themeless pursuit.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:description: An ice palace in St. Petersburg, built in 2006, copied one that was made for Empress Anna Ioannovna of Russia in the 1700s.

item.title: Mamdani Creates Office to Encourage Public Participation in Government
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York said he hoped to reach communities that had been left out of the process.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays

media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani introduces Ali Najmi at a news conference on Friday. Mr. Najmi, a civil rights and election lawyer, will chair the Mayor’s Advisory Committee on the Judiciary.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Many People Gambling on Health Premiums for Obamacare Double
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 3, 2026.

item.title: Harrowing Videos Show the Swiss Bar Fire’s Rapid Spread
item.description: Videos shared on social media and verified by The New York Times show how the blaze quickly tore through a popular bar during a New Year’s celebration in the Alps, killing at least 40 people and injuring more than a hundred others.
item.dc:creator: Chevaz Clarke, Ainara Tiefenthäler and Aric Toler

item.title: ‘Stranger Things’ llegó a su fin. ¿Qué pasó con Eleven y sus amigos?
item.description: Por diez años compartimos aventuras con los chicos y chicas de Hawkins, un pueblo ficticio de Indiana que capturó todo el candor de los años ochenta.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray

item.title: Stephen Schwartz Criticizes Kennedy Center, Saying He Won’t Host Gala
item.description: The Washington National Opera said the “Wicked” composer was scheduled to host its annual event at the center this spring.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Adam Nagourney
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:description: “There’s no way I would set foot in it now,” Stephen Schwartz said of the Kennedy Center, which has seen many changes during the second Trump administration.

item.title: Software Error Will Force 325,000 Californians to Replace Real IDs
item.description: Some state-issued identification cards issued to legal immigrants could be valid longer than the people holding them are allowed to remain in the United States, state officials said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

media:content.media:credit: Lea Suzuki/The San Francisco Chronicle, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A California Department of Motor Vehicles office in San Francisco. The department said that 1.5 percent of the state’s Real ID holders were affected by a software glitch and must replace their cards.

item.title: Mamdani Creates Office of Mass Engagement
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani announced two appointments at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn on his second day as mayor of New York City, including the creation of an Office of Mass Engagement.
item.dc:creator: Jackeline Luna

media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani introduces Ali Najmi at a news conference on Friday. Mr. Najmi, a civil rights and election lawyer, will chair the Mayor’s Advisory Committee on the Judiciary.

item.title: Trump Super PAC Raised More Than $100 Million in Recent Months
item.description: The haul highlights how the president’s team has continued aggressive fund-raising from donors with interests before the administration.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel and Karen Yourish

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The biggest donors to a super PAC devoted to President Trump have ties to artificial intelligence and cryptocurrency.

item.title: Behind the Scenes With Our Photographer
item.description: “I have a lot of gear.” Our photographer Chang W. Lee describes how he plans to capture the journey to Antarctica from every angle, including from a long-range drone and a sound-triggered camera designed to capture a calving glacier.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Lee, Raymond Zhong, Christina Thornell, Kassie Bracken, Sutton Raphael, Leila Medina and Adam Hogan

item.title: An
item.description: Our reporter sends a dispatch from the icebreaker Araon, currently on its way to Antarctica, about the scientists, their work and how he’s battling seasickness.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

item.title: Your Antarctica Questions, Answered
item.description: Our reporter Raymond Zhong takes a first round of questions about the trip to Antarctica. First up: How can data gathered on the trip tell us how much time is left for the glaciers?
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Rebecca Suner, Stephanie Swart and Christina Thornell

item.title: Un petrolero que huye de la Guardia Costera difunde su ubicación en el Atlántico Norte
item.description: Rusia solicitó esta semana que Estados Unidos pusiera fin a su persecución del buque, que fue interceptado en el Caribe cuando se dirigía a recoger petróleo en Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Nicholas Nehamas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: El petrolero Bella 1, fotografiado en marzo. Recientemente ha aparecido en el registro oficial de buques de Rusia con un nuevo nombre, Marinera.

item.title: Dick Zimmer, N.J. Congressman Who Sponsored Megan’s Law, Dies at 81
item.description: The landmark legislation, a response to the rape and murder of a New Jersey child, required states to disclose where convicted sex-offenders live.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

media:content.media:credit: Laura Patterson/CQ Roll Call, via Associated Press Images
media:content.media:description: Representative Dick Zimmer, second from left, during a House hearing in 1996. His legislation targeting sex offenders was passed unanimously by the House and Senate and signed into law by President Bill Clinton that year.

item.title: Offshore Wind Projects Challenge Trump Administration’s Order to Stop Work
item.description: The developers of Revolution Wind off Rhode Island and Empire Wind off New York are the latest to sue the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman

media:content.media:description: Wind-turbine parts for the Revolution Wind offshore project in New London, Conn., in September.

item.title: Swiss Bar Fire Likely Caused By Sparklers, Authorities Say
item.description: Fireworks attached to bottles of Champagne sent up showers of sparks that appear to have ignited insulation in a bar. The blaze killed 40 people.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic, Aurelien Breeden and Thomas Fuller

media:content.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A memorial outside the Constellation bar in Crans-Montana, Switzerland, on Friday, the day after 40 people died there in a fire.

item.title: Sprinkles Cupcakes, the Bakery That Sold From Vending Machines, Closes Suddenly
item.description: The boutique chain’s co-founder, Candace Nelson, said that the business had ceased operations at year’s end. It was sold to a private equity firm more than a decade ago.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser

item.title: Overlooked No More: Pamela Colman Smith, Artist Behind a Famous Tarot Deck
item.description: She hand-painted around 80 illustrations for the Rider-Waite deck, which is still used around the world to predict destinies.
item.dc:creator: Emily Palmer

item.title: Hiker Killed in Suspected Mountain Lion Attack, Colorado’s First in Decades
item.description: A woman’s body was found on a trail on Crosier Mountain this week, with a mountain lion nearby.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel

media:content.media:description: If confirmed, the attack would be the first fatal attack by a mountain lion in Colorado since 1999, when a 3-year-old boy was killed.

item.title: Coast Guard Suspends Search for Survivors of Latest Boat Strikes
item.description: The service said that conditions in the area where the search was taking place included nine-foot seas and winds approaching 50 miles per hour.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A Coast Guard ship at Coast Guard Base San Juan on Wednesday. The strike on Tuesday was the fourth known instance of people surviving, at least initially, one of the 35 military strikes against boats in the Caribbean Sea and the eastern Pacific.

item.title: California’s Latest Storm Brings Flooding to San Francisco Bay Area
item.description: The state has seen a nonstop run of storms in recent weeks. This one is expected to bring heavy rain through the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff and Soumya Karlamangla

media:content.media:description: A jogger ran through floodwaters amid a king tide in Mill Valley, Calif., on Friday.

item.title: Saks C.E.O. Steps Down as Company Struggles to Pay Down Debt
item.description: Saks Global’s executive chairman, Richard Baker, is taking over the luxury retailer he created with the 2024 acquisition of Neiman Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin, Vanessa Friedman and Lauren Hirsch

media:content.media:description: Marc Metrick, who started running Saks Fifth Avenue in 2015, is stepping down as chief executive of Saks Global.

item.title: Trump Says He Takes a High Daily Dose of Aspirin. How Safe Is That?
item.description: Despite his doctors’ recommendations, President Trump takes a high dose.
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.category: United States Preventive Services Task Force

item.title: Waterlogged California Braces for More Rain
item.description: Heavy rain has drenched California since mid-December, causing flooding and landslides. The National Weather Service forecasts another 1 to 6 inches of rain will fall this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling

media:content.media:credit: Ronaldo Bolaños/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images

item.title: D.C. Pipe Bomb Suspect Ordered to Remain in Jail Until Trial
item.description: A magistrate judge said he was concerned that the defendant, Brian Cole Jr., had continued after Jan. 6, 2021, to purchase components similar to those prosecutors said he had used to make pipe bombs.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

media:content.media:description: Surveillance footage from January 2021 showed the man authorities identified as Brian Cole Jr. He told investigators he felt relieved that the bombs had not exploded and that no one was hurt.

item.title: Violinist on Will Smith’s Tour Files Wrongful Termination Lawsuit
item.description: A lawyer for the musician, Brian King Joseph, says in the court papers that Mr. Joseph was fired after reporting sexual harassment.
item.dc:creator: Jason M. Bailey

media:content.media:description: Will Smith and his production company were accused in a lawsuit of wrongfully firing a violinist who performed on Mr. Smith’s “Based on a True Story” concert tour.

item.title: Este diminuto reptil juega a piedra, papel o tijera
item.description: Un estudio reciente revela la biología invisible que hace posible el juego y muestra cómo este puede ser una fuente importante de la diversidad de la naturaleza.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, Jan. 3, 2026
item.description: Can you sort 8 historical events?

item.title: Israeli Government Accuses Mamdani of Antisemitism Over Canceled Orders
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York canceled executive orders issued by his predecessor that had barred city agencies from boycotting Israel and defined some criticism of Israel as antisemitic.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Jeffery C. Mays

media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani has been a strong critic of Israel and its treatment of the Palestinians throughout his public life.

item.title: In Trump’s Second Year, Congress Weighs How to Reassert Its Power
item.description: Lawmakers head into President Trump’s second year facing questions about whether they can reclaim congressional clout in the face of his power grab.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: Ringing in 2026 on an Icebreaker Bound for Antarctica
item.description: Scientists aboard the icebreaker Araon welcomed 2026 with games, another time change and a soup that marks the years ticking past.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

media:content.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Scientists aboard the South Korean icebreaker Araon rang in the new year on their way to Antarctica.

item.title: What to Expect From Mayor Mamdani
item.description: Readers share their hopes and anxieties as New York’s new mayor takes office. Also: Unsubscribing from the Kennedy Center; protesting Trump.
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mr. Mamdani said New York could be a proving ground for democratic socialist ideas across the country and even the world.

item.title: Oil Tanker Fleeing U.S. Coast Guard Broadcasts Location in North Atlantic
item.description: Russia requested this week that the United States end its pursuit of the vessel, which was intercepted in the Caribbean on its way to pick up oil in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Nicholas Nehamas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: The oil tanker Bella 1, photographed in March. It recently appeared in Russia’s official register of ships under a new name, the Marinera.

item.title: Richard Pollak, 91, Dies; Edited Magazine That Criticized the Media
item.description: He was a founder of More, which skewered the foibles of the press in the 1970s, and later wrote a critical biography of the psychoanalyst Bruno Bettelheim.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: Democratic Socialists Celebrate Mayor Mamdani With a Rave in Brooklyn
item.description: Democratic Socialists gathered at a Bushwick dance club to celebrate as one of their members began to govern New York City.
item.dc:creator: Jesse McKinley and Nina Westervelt

media:content.media:description: Councilmembers Alexa Avilés, left, and Tiffany Cabán.

item.title: A Rescuer Recounts How He Saved Lives During Swiss Bar Resort Fire
item.description: Nestor Fischer, 17, forced open a blocked door at Le Constellation, the Swiss bar that caught fire on New Year’s Day
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic

media:content.media:credit: Til Bürgy for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Authorities shielded Le Constellation bar and lounge on Friday to conduct an investigation following the deadly fire on New Year’s Day.

item.title: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’ 2025 Book Recommendations
item.description: Readings that the podcast’s guests say shaped their thinking.

item.title: North Carolina Man Accused of Planning Potential Terrorist Attack
item.description: The 18-year-old, radicalized online, was planning a New Year’s Eve attack in a Charlotte suburb, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

media:content.media:credit: Logan R. Cyrus for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The accused man is from Mint Hill, N.C.

item.title: Sparklers Probably Caused Deadly Fire at Swiss Ski Resort, Officials Say
item.description: The bar in the Swiss Alps where the blaze occurred was popular with people in their late teens and early 20s. Friends and families have been mounting desperate searches for updates on their loved ones.
item.dc:creator: Axel Boada

media:content.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A makeshift memorial on Friday outside the Le Constellation bar, after a fire in Crans-Montana, Switzerland.

item.title: Cómo un incendio arrasó un bar suizo y rompió el corazón de un pueblo
item.description: El siniestro, que el presidente suizo calificó de una de las peores catástrofes de la historia de Suiza, dejó a la localidad turística de Crans-Montana en estado de shock.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic and Til Bürgy

media:content.media:credit: Til Bürgy for The New York Times

item.title: Book Review: ‘American Reich,’ by Eric Lichtblau
item.description: In “American Reich,” the former New York Times journalist Eric Lichtblau dissects the culture of hate that led to the death of a gay man in Southern California.
item.dc:creator: Elon Green
item.category: American Reich: A Murder in Orange County, Neo-Nazis, and a New Age of Hate (Book)

media:content.media:description: Samuel Woodward at a hearing in 2018 in California.

item.title: Should You Tell a Stranger That She Has Bird Poop on Her Shoulder?
item.description: A ruling on a matter of coffee-shop etiquette.
item.dc:creator: John Hodgman
